results.title: Aspirations
results.creator_credit: James Beveridge and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Crossroads of the world: a study of North Africa and the Middle East”.
Education, political reform, and technology are all being used to serve the aims of the society of North Africa and the Middle East. The primary aim is liberation from colonial control and from the grip of poverty. Throughout the region this film finds much new development, aimed for the most part at the production of larger, more varied crops and the organization of new industry. Within sight of the waterwheels of antiquity can be seen the rise of vast power dams and pumping stations, and beyond mud villages steel and concrete cities, schools and factories can be seed.
results.creator_credit_for_label: James Beveridge and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Notes on a harpsichord
results.creator_credit: David Cheshire, John Read and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Craftsman”.
Follows a harpsichord from its construction to a concert performance. Philip Ledger, who is Musical Director of the Aldeburgh Festival and is one of Britain’s finest continuo players, describes the basic features of the harpsichord, and introduces the man who maintains and tunes his own harpsichord for concert performance - Malcolm Russell.

results.title: David Coleman: cabinet maker
results.creator_credit: Michael Dibb, John Read and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Craftsman”.
David Coleman and his assistants make beautiful reproduction antique furniture in a workshop in the little village of Stebbing, Essex, almost all of which is exported to the U.S.A

results.title: Matcham Skipper: metal sculptor
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Craftman and His Environment”.
A study of Matcham Skipper, one of Australia’s best known workers in silver, making jewellery and sculpting in silver at his studio in the old artists’ colony of Montsalvat, Victoria, in 1973. The film features the process of lost-wax casting. The film was funded by the Crafts Board of the Australia Council.

results.title: The Colonies look ahead
results.creator_credit: John Howe, Ronald Dick and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”.
A film survey of economic development, education and race relations in various British colonial territories. Progress in representative colonies, such as Kenya, is assessed on the basis of their ability to manage their own affairs and to achieve self-government. Narrated by Edgar McInnis.

results.title: Crisis in Asia
results.creator_credit: John Howe, Ronald Dick and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”.
This film reviews the tumultuous past of India, Pakistan and Ceylon up to the events in recent history that saw these countries attain full independence. We meet the heroes of the independence movement - Mahatma Gandhi, Prime Minister Nehru, and Muhammed Ali Jinnah - and see how their work bore fruit. Edgar McInnis delves into the commonality of Commonwealth aspirations as exemplified in the free choice of these three nations to remain in the Commonwealth after their colonial ties with Britain had been cut.

results.title: Colonialism: ogre or angel?
results.creator_credit: Ronald Dick and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”.
How the British colonial empire grew is a story as full of adventure as it is of contrast. This film takes us to British colonies, protectorates and protected states to see the impact of industrialization on colonial people, and their awakening desire for self-determination. Narrated by Edgar McInnis.

results.title: Can it hold together?
results.creator_credit: Ronald Dick, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”.
To examine this question, the film brings into focus recent historic events as recorded by the motion picture camera. We see the Commonwealth members in the arena of world affairs frequently taking diverging views on international issues but able, through their very differences, to serve as channels of communication between countries outside the Commonwealth. Edgar McInnis analyses some paradoxical situations that have arisen during the course of the Cold War, in which differing views and opposing loyalties inside the Commonwealth have helped to offset an East-West split. Narrated by Edgar McInnis.
